question: Google Scholar
answer:
The Libraries web site tab for Google Scholar should activate link resolving and make subscribed resources available.  In the event this doesn't work (most likely for off-campus users), the following workaround is available:

-Go straight to Google Scholar online (instead of through the library's website) at https://scholar.google.com <https://scholar.google.com/>.
-Set up Library Links for Miami University:
-After going to https://scholar.google.com <https://scholar.google.com/>, click the Menu icon in the top left next to "Google Scholar".
-Click Settings.
-Click Library Links.
-Type Miami University into the search box and hit enter.
-Check the box next to "Miami University Libraries - Find It @MiamiOH".
-Click Save.




This will allow patrons to see the "Find it @MiamiOH" link on Google Scholar search results even if they haven't authenticated through the library website, and should allow off campus access to full text.

question: Journal impact factors
answer:
Journal Impact Factors can be found in the Journal Citation Reports <http://www.lib.miamioh.edu/indexes/redirect/1271> databases. 

Journal Impact Factor is the average number of times articles from the journal published in the past two years have been cited in the JCR year.  The impact factor is calculated by dividing the number of citations in the JCR year by the total number of citations of articles published in the two previous years. An impact factor of 1.0 means that, on average, the articles published one or two year ago have been cited one time. An impact factor of 2.5 means that, on average, the articles published one or two year ago have been cited two and a half times. Citing articles may be from the same journal; most citing articles are from different journals. The impact factor mitigates the importance of absolute citation frequencies. It tends to discount the advantage of large journals over small journals because large journals produce a larger body of citable literature. For the same reason, it tends to discount the advantage of frequently issued journals over less frequently issued ones and of older journals over newer ones. Because it offsets the advantages of size and age, it is a valuable tool for journal evaluation.

General information about Journal Citation Reports and other research impact tools like Ulrich's, Cabell's, Google Scholar, and Publish or Perish can be found online at http://libguides.lib.miamioh.edu/dossier.

question: While downloading articles, I received a message saying that I have been temporarily blocked for making too many requests. What gives?
answer: Our off campus authentication system is set up to block users who download very large files in order to prevent accounts that may be compromised from illegally using our licensed content. Sometimes the system mistakenly blocks legit users, also.  The suspensions automatically lift after 15 minutes, so usually by the time we're alerted to the problem the suspension has expired.

question: Can faculty place personally-owned copies of books on reserve?
answer:
The Libraries will affix a barcode, reserve labels, and theft detection devices to personal copies provided to us for reserve. Personal materials are returned to you through campus mail unless otherwise indicated. The library is not responsible for the loss of, or damage to, personal copies.

Fill out a Reserve Request Form and deliver materials to be placed on reserve to a Circulation desk for processing. You may use our web-based request form <http://www.lib.miamioh.edu/reserve-request-form>.

The week before and the first week of Fall and Spring semesters are busy times. To ensure that materials are available for students when needed, at the start of each semester allow one week for library staff to process materials for reserves. At other times, please allow 2 working days.

Loan periods for course materials are chosen by the instructor. Options are 2 hour checkouts (For Use in the Library only); 1-day or 3-days

All personal materials are removed at the end of every semester. Any materials donated to the Libraries are returned to the circulating collection.

question: Which Library films and videos have public performance rights?
answer:
The Libraries own VHS tapes, DVDs and laserdiscs, some of which may include public performance rights. Please contact Karen Clift <mailto:cliftks@miamioh.edu?subject=Film%20PPR> to determine if the library purchased public performance rights for an individual title.

-Library-owned films on DVD, laserdisc, and VHS DO NOT include public performance rights UNLESS you see a note in the catalog record that states otherwise.
-Showing library-owned films outside of the classroom without public performance rights may be illegal.
-If the library did not purchase public performance rights, it is the responsibility of the individual or organization intending to publicly screen the film to secure public performance rights.
-Acquisitions and cataloging staff maintain a list of public performance rights by producer/distributor <http://publicperformancerights.pbworks.com/w/page/30539346/FrontPage>.


Streaming videos available to faculty, staff, and students may also be found by searching the title of the video in the Books & More <http://proxy.lib.miamioh.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?authtype=ip&profile=eds_cat> tab on the Libraries' website. 

You may also browse streaming videos in the following databases:

Alexander Street Press <http://www.lib.miamioh.edu/indexes/redirect/905>

OhioLINK Educational and Instructional Videos <http://www.lib.miamioh.edu/indexes/redirect/282>

Films in the streaming databases above include public performance rights as long as no admission fee is charged.

question: Gifts in Kind Policy
answer:
The Miami University Libraries welcomes the donation of gifts-in-kind not already in library collections in the following categories:

-Hardback or trade paperback books in good to excellent condition
-CDs and DVDs in good playable condition in their original cases


Because of reduced staff we cannot accept the following:

-Mass-market paperbacks
-Textbooks more than 2 years old
-Journal articles, issues or volumes*
-Folders, binders
-Theses, dissertations
-VHS or audio cassette tapes
-Vinyl records (33 (LP), 45 or 78 rpm)
-Mildewed or musty materials of any type


All donations of gifts-in-kind are accepted with the understanding that the Libraries will retain only those materials that meet our collection needs. These decisions are made at the discretion of the subject librarian.

The Libraries cannot assist in packing or transporting donated materials. On campus, the donor’s department may contact the trucking crew to arrange transportation of large collections. Off campus, the donor should arrange transportation to the King Library shipping room door (off the drive between King Library and McGuffey Hall). Please contact the Libraries about your gift before arranging for delivery.

If you wish to claim a donation as a tax deduction, please be aware that the Libraries are not permitted to provide any appraisal or value estimate. The donor is responsible for following IRS rules. Once accepted, donations become the property of Miami University and cannot be returned to donors.

Donors who believe their materials are of special value or of historical significance should contact Walter Havighurst Special Collections (513 529-3323).

For further information or to discuss your gift plans, please contact Library Acquisitions, 513 529-2886.

Thank you for your cooperation and support of the Miami University Libraries.

*The Libraries currently provide most journals in an electronic format. A complete run of a print journal not available online will be considered as an exception.

Last Updated: 5/29/2012

question: LAS 208
answer:
LAS 208

Question: "I need to find travel writing written by a person originally from outside of the region they're writing about, within a particular time period."

Answer (per Katie Gibson): 
-Pick a country or region (Central America, South America, Caribbean). Latin America is too general of a term.
-Add the phrase "description and travel" to the search terms.
-Narrow your search results by date to your time period 
OR 
If that does not find results, go back to the full results list. Some books were written two hundred years ago but republished recently. When you narrow the results by date, these will be removed from the list.
-Make sure the book is not a guide for travelers, but rather a book by someone talking about their trip to the country. 
-
You can also direct them to me or to the research guide I made for the assignment. 
http://libguides.lib.miamioh.edu/las/LAS208

question: Procedures for print outages
answer:
Sometimes all print services in the library go down. This can mean that nothing is showing up in the print queue. It could also mean that students are unable to swipe and pay for their print job.

Before concluding that all services are down, please troubleshoot the issue for yourself. Send a test print job. Try to replicate the problem before assuming that something is simply broken. 

If services are down, and after reporting the issue to Library Systems and IT Services through the form <http://staff.lib.miamioh.edu/printproblems/printproblems.html>, please adhere to the following procedures: 
-Hang out of order signs on ALL affected printers and/or VTS machines. 
-Print for patrons on staff printers, at no cost, using ULB-KNG101-M401dne (the Information Desk printer) or ULB-KNG101-ir-C5035 (the Circulation Desk printer).
-Please do not handle all free print requests yourself, especially if a long line is forming. Once you're helping 1-2 patrons, direct other patrons to the Information Desk and Circulation Desk.
